text:
Hello. I'm a virtual advisor.


I'm here to help you find the right information and advice about keeping well and independent after leaving hospital
Looks like you got distracted. We can continue later.
I’m not a real person, but I've been made by real people.
The questions I ask are automated, but the answers I give are based on your input.
I can give information to people who are leaving hospital and need to organise some help for when they get home.
Does that sound OK?
Great. I'll need to ask you a couple of questions to get started. Is that OK?
Great. First things first. Can I ask your name so that I know what to call you?
Thanks {{vars.name}}. Are you answering these questions for yourself or for someone else?
OK.
Here are some other options I've found for you...
You can visit LivingWell Essex for information about care and health support in Essex.
Or Essex.gov.uk for more information on local health and social care.
Or go to the NHS website to find out more general information and advice on healthcare and services.
OK. What would you like to do instead?
OK. Can you tell me how old you are? This is so I can direct you to the right sort of information.
Thanks. Now, I want to find out types of things would help you stay well when you leave hospital.

OK. Can you tell me how old they are? 


This is so I can direct you to the right sort of information.
Thanks. Now, I want to find out types of things would help them stay well when they leave hospital.
OK. You've chosen maintaining and adapting your home.
What would you like to know more about?

quick_replies.title: Adapting your home to get around
quick_replies.payload: Adapting your home to get around

options.pattern: Adapting your home to get around

text: You can make changes to your home to help manage everyday tasks and stay independent.
There are small changes that can be made to your home.    These are called "minor adaptations". For example:
grab rails around the bath
shower or toilet
grab rails by the front or back door
additional stair rails
small steps to doors
There are also significant changes.
These are called "major adaptations" and cost more. For example:
level access showers or wet rooms
stairlifts or through-floor lifts
wheelchair ramps
widening doorways
adapting kitchens
What would you like to do now?

options.pattern: Find out about paying for adaptations yourself
Find out what help you can get with paying for adaptations
Go back to maintaining your home

text: Getting your house repaired or decorated can improve your quality of life and keep you enjoying your home for longer.
There are various ways to organise repairs and decorating

quick_replies.title: Arrange for repairs and decorating yourself

text: Hoarding is where someone collects a large number of items and keeps them in an untidy way. It can become a health and safety hazard because it's difficult to clean and can cause trips and falls.
It's important you try to keep your home as clutter-free as you can to avoid hazards and risk to your health.

quick_replies.title: Find out how your local council can help
quick_replies.payload: Find out how your local council can help

options.pattern: Find out how your local council can help

text: NHS Choices provides information and advice on hoarding disorders.
You can get advice on fire safety at home from the Essex County Fire and Rescue Service.
And read London Fire Brigade's leaflet on safety tips for hoarders and learn how to reduce the risk of fire.
You can choose to make minor adaptations yourself.
The Disabled Living Foundation gives information, advice and a list of suppliers to help you choose.
Find tradespeople near you:
Age UK gives advice on types of home adaptations to help make your home life easier.
You could get support for minor adaptations costing up to £1000.
You can ask Essex County Council Adult Social Care to carry out an assessment to see if minor adaptations will help you manage everyday tasks at home.
Would you like to know about help with major adaptations?
If you're disabled or have a long-term health condition and need to make changes to your home, you might be able to get a disabled facilities grant.
Would you like to request an assessment?
What would you like to do next?

quick_replies.title: More about maintaining and adpating your home
quick_replies.payload: More about maintaining and adpating your home

options.pattern: More about maintaining and adpating your home

text: How can I help you?
If you are a council tenant, you may be eligible for financial help for home improvements. Contact your local council for more information...
Would you like to contact your local council about repairs and improvements?
This is help_with_repairs
If you're worried about yourself or someone else, speak to your GP for advice.
Your local council's adult social care team may be able to offer support. An adult social care worker will carry out an assessment of the person's needs with them.
Essex Floating Support Service offers help with clutter or hoarding. This is a free service offered to vulnerable people who need support with housing related issues.

quick_replies.title: Adapting your home to get around
quick_replies.payload: Adapting your home to get around

text: Equipment to help with dressing includes:
button hookers
dressing sticks and zip pullers
sock and stocking aids to help you put them on
long-handed shoe horns to make it easier to get your shoes on and off
Equipment to help you with washing includes:
tap turners, lever taps and automatic taps if you have problems with your grip
grab rails to help you get in and out of the bath or shower
a bath board, bath seat or bath lift to make it easier and safer to use the bath
shower boards and swivel seats to help you get in and out of the bath
long-handled sponges and brushes to help you wash your back and feet
Equipment to help in the toilet includes:
raised toilet seats and toilet rails to make it easier to get on or off the toilet
long-handed bottom wipers to help you clean yourself after going to the toilet
waterproof bedding and mattresses can help manage incontinence
Equipment to help you prepare and cook food includes:
kettle-tippers and lightweight kettles
non-slip mats  bottle, jar and tin openers
food choppers
spreader boards
utensils with large, long, weighed or curved grips
There is technology that can help you stay independent in your home and better connected with your community.
Alarms, sensors, monitors and detectors can be placed around your home or worn.
They can keep you safe and help make life easier for you and those that care for you
Try The Disabled Living Foundation's Ask SARA tool. It gives advice on equipment and where to get them.
Would you like to find out how to get some of this equipment?

text: This is pay_for_equipment
Here is a list of services that might be able to help you find equipment:
The Disabled Living Foundation's Ask SARA tool gives advice on equipment and where to get them
Essex Cares Ltd (ECL) provides sensory and equipment services on behalf of Essex County Council
Age UK  gives information and advice on using technology for independence.
The Red Cross  offers short-term loans of some equipment
NHS Choices can provide more information and advice on equipment to make life easier
What would you like help with next?
OK. You've chosen getting around in your home.

quick_replies.title: Exercises you can do in the home
quick_replies.payload: Exercises you can do in the home

quick_replies.title: Equipment to help you get around
quick_replies.payload: Equipment to help you get around

options.pattern: Exercises you can do in the home
Equipment to help you get around

text: Here are some of the most effective ways to help prevent falls:

* removing clutter, trailing wires and frayed carpet
* using non-slip mats and rugs
* using high-wattage light bulbs in lamps and torches, so you can see clearly
* organising your home so that climbing, stretching and bending are kept to a minimum, and to avoid bumping into things

* not walking on slippery floors in socks or tights
* not wearing loose-fitting, trailing clothes that might trip you up
* wearing well-fitting shoes that are in good condition and support the ankle
* taking care of your feet by trimming your toenails regularly and seeing a GP or chiropodist about any foot problems
You can find more falls prevention tips on the NHS website
AgeUK also provide information on how to avoid falls
There are lots of simple exercises that you can do in your own home to improve your strength and mobility.
Try these exercises to improve your balance.
And combine them with these exercises to improve strength.
And these to improve flexibility
And here are some exercises you can even do sitting down.
Some equipment and daily living aids can make it easier for you to live at home and stay independent.
And if you're caring for someone, equipment could help make your work easier and safer.
What tasks do you think equipment might help you with?
Where would you like to go next?
Physiotherapy is a treatment to improve movement, flexibility, coordination and strength. It helps people who are experiencing difficulties with their walking.
Would you like to find a physiotherapist?
You might be referred to physiotherapist following a hospital stay, or after seeing a GP, district nurse or social worker.
Find out about ECL (Essex Cares Ltd) physiotherapy services.
Or if you want to find private physiotherapists in your area, try these links:
Chartered Society of Physiotherapy
Physio First

text: Looks like you got distracted. We can continue later.
Your local council offers a service that assesses your home and recommends equipment or adaptations.
Having a home assessment is free.
Your council could pay for equipment that costs less than £1,000. Ask social services at your local council about getting a home assessment.
Would you like to speak to someone about a home assessment?
If you're finding it difficult to look after yourself and manage everyday tasks, you can contact Essex County Council to talk about your care and support needs.
Would you like to speak to someone about organising care?
Most people have to pay something towards their care and support.
The local council can work out how much you might pay by carrying out a financial assessment.
Find out more at Essex.gov.uk
Would you like to speak to someone about paying for care?
